    Mr R. Jumabhoy (Telok Ayer): Mr Speaker, Sir, at the close of yesterday's sitting, I started saying that some argued whether Mr and Mrs Singapore should have a fixed limit of children because of economic reasons. Sir, do the majority of Singaporeans believe in this? It is for them to judge. Personally, I would say that anybody for health reasons can take advice; but, on principle if the Government are going to give a donation, it should be a token donation to a private body - as the Government are giving to others - but if the Government are going to be very beneficent, then they should run this department under the General Hospital division or the Health Department. Some say that religious objections should not be respected. I say respect them. Government should not do what is objected by others. But if it were a Government department, no taxpayer would raise a protest that Government is doing this or that. The protest is against giving such a big sum of money to a private body.

    Sir, as I said, I do not question the integrity of these welfare workers. Many of us have worked in private bodies and associations for the welfare of the people and they can help the Government in that way.

    Now, Sir, I want to ask the Hon, the Financial Secretary some questions. This $100,000 is given from the rate-payers' money, to which many are objecting on religious grounds; first, what voice have the Government got as to how and where the Family Planning Association should spend this money? Secondly, have the Government any financial check as to how the money is being spent, where it is being spent and so on? Thirdly, have the Government any nominee on this Association? If the Government have not got sufficient control, the best thing is to place this Association under the control of the Health Department.

    Mr Goh Tong Liang (Bukit Panjang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I went through the statistics yesterday and I am now going to a different aspect of the question.

Column: 1378



    It will be interesting to know what is really behind the whole question of family planning. Are those who urge and organise these activities activated by the love for children? If so, it seems a strange expression of that love that they should endeavour to stop the coming of children into the world. Are they inspired with the ambition to procure for everybody a higher standard of living? There are factors in society of far greater importance than a higher standard of living. The Chinese squatter, who tills his little patch of land on the hillside in the island of Singapore, or who raises chickens and tends to his egg-producing hens in the district of Mandai, is a happy man. His standard of living no doubt is not high. He and his family are no drain on the economy of Singapore. He sells his produce to his neighbours and buys theirs in return. Above all, he is a happy man. His children are happy and carefree. Their names are not on the police records. If I am told that in ten years' time Singapore will have another million of such children, I am not worried at all. But when I see one family growing up with the understanding that, when the age of puberty comes, they shall be free to give full rein to their sex instinct, then I will really and truly be worried.

    History has shown that with the release of the sex instinct come all sorts of vices. Man's instincts cannot be isolated from one another. Release one and all break their bonds. Release sex and man's principles of right and wrong become confused. His judgment becomes confused. Let sex release become general and the weakness of man becomes a weakness of the community. The delicate balance needed for social adjustment is thrown off and we have confusion - family confusion, social confusion, national and international confusion - all leading eventually to a horrid fear of war, or to actual war, and our total destruction.

    On the other hand, what danger are a million babies in ten years from now if they are decent, well-educated babies?

Column: 1379



    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Where to get the money from?

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: It is up to the Government! Might we not direct our efforts towards that direction? Might we not invite our family planning friends to change their names and become character-planners instead?

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Idealist!

    Mr Goh Tong Liang: Would the $100,000 not be better spent on advertising the benefit of leading an honest life according to the standard laws of old-time conduct? Have we ever thought of trusting the people of Singapore, of asking them to come forward with ideas on how Singapore may be made morally better? If we have never tried, it is useless to throw up our hands and say that we cannot succeed. Family planning will stop a baby, but it will not stop wars. It will not stop gangsterism in Singapore. It will not relieve the police of one single headache.

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng (Changi): Sir, I rise early this morning to endorse every word just delivered by the Member for Bukit Panjang. He has supplied us with many details on the subject which he has touched on so learnedly, especially from the moral point of view. In my opinion, seldom have the speakers touched on the moral point of view in this debate.

    Sir, it has been said that the Catholics are only against family planning. I think that is quite wrong. Last night I had a chance to meet many church and community leaders and we discussed this subject. They said they objected not only from the religious point of view, but also from the moral point of view. They said, "Family planning will easily lead our people into becoming irresponsible." Sir, I will quote an example of how irresponsible people can be. For example, the Member for Tanjong Pagar - why has he not turned up this morning? Why did he not yesterday -

Column: 1380



    The Chairman: Order. That, of course, is touching on the personal conduct of an hon. Member, and no comment can be made as to why a Member is absent, whether we are on family planning or not!

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, what I mean to say is that they make sure as to whether they will have any responsibility or not. For example, in family planning, they teach you a lot of art; how to get everything free without any responsibility, and so sure of getting all the pleasure you want. And there is no burden to shoulder later on. That is why I like to ask, "Why are the P.A.P. representatives not interested in taking part in the debate?" Because, Sir, they are not so sure they will succeed in wooing the support of U.M.N.O.

    Some hon. Members: No!

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: But they are so sure that regarding the Constitution the "piggies" are on their side, Sir.

    The Chairman: Order. If the hon. Member will not confine himself to the debate, then of course I will have to stop him. We are now on family planning, and not on politics.

    The Chief Minister (Tun Lim Yew Hock): Political planning!

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: Sir, I am sorry! I beg your pardon! I was only quoting an example to show how human nature can easily be led into irresponsibility. A practical example for this House to consider is the Family Planning Association. If you go to the Family Planning Association, you know you will get everything, any advice you want, and then the danger can arise. Therefore, I purposely quoted an example to show that when a person is not so sure that he can get what he wants, he is not interested at all. I say that the Family Planning Association can easily bring up the divorce rate and cause more mental patients. In the so-called higher developed countries unclaimed children are quite common. But that is not so common in Eastern countries. Why? Because we do not

Column: 1381

believe in family planning. We believe in morals. We live on a spiritual rather than on a material plane. The Family Planning Association is a contrast to our Eastern culture and beliefs.

    Mr Chew Swee Kee: Mr Speaker, Sir, we have this morning been assailed with lectures on sociology, sexology and moral standards. Yesterday, we were told to be confident. I had not intended to speak this morning but for the fact that I have been misrepresented as saying that the figure of $975 million I mentioned was the cost of running the Education Department. I wish to make it clear that the figure of $975 million is the capital expenditure required to build the 290 odd schools if we were to absorb one million children under the age of 14.

10.15 a.m.

    As regards the estimated cost required to educate all these children, I have taken the present basis and multiplied it by four - that is, we need about four times the teachers. Therefore, the annual recurrent expenditure and personal emoluments will rise by about four times, which means that we will have to spend $256 million on annual recurrent items and on personal emoluments, and that is in excess of the capital expenditure required. That brings me to another point, and that is we have to have about 34,000 to 35,000 teachers. At present, we have about 9,000 teachers and if we have a population of one million children in school, we will have to have about 34,000 to 35,000 teachers. That will again lead to the provision for training of these teachers and the provision of more training colleges. At present, the Training College that we have can take 3,000 teachers at a time for training. That is the maximum. Now, if we are going to have about 34,000 or 35,000 teachers, we will need 12 colleges. Has the Member for Changi suggested any practical means to meet all this expenditure?

    Again, with the number of children in school, there will be need for more trade schools, vocational schools, polytechnics and universities. Does the Member for

Column: 1382

Changi realise that one trade school will cost at least $2 million to build and equip? These are facts staring at us in the face. The speakers who have opposed this grant to the Family Planning Association have not touched on how to deal with such problems. These are the problems that will come and face us, as I said, in about ten years' time. The Members have given nothing but abstract ideas - ideas of confidence and moral standards. I have yet to hear one person say how we are going to face such serious problems in about ten years' time.

    The Minister for Health (Mr A. J. Braga): Mr Speaker, Sir, when I rose yesterday to support this motion, I specifically said that all arguments for and against had been fully discussed previously and that there was hardly any necessity for a prolonged debate.

    Having heard some of the fallacious arguments put forward yesterday and today - and that by some of my colleagues - I feel it incumbent upon me to answer some of these. Hon. Members will remember that I had previously repeated that on a subject such as this, one voted according to one's conscience, and that religion should not be introduced as a basis for argument.

    Unfortunately, my colleague the Minister for Commerce and Industry sought to introduce religion and advanced the argument that although the Muslim religion forbade anything to do with pork, yet money was being spent on pig-rearing.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: On a point of information, Sir, It is very clear that I did not introduce the religion motive in the debate. It was introduced by an Opposition Member and I was only just pointing out that it was all very confusing to introduce religion into this sort of a debate.

    Mr Braga: But he did say that although the Muslim religion forbade anything to do with pork, yet money was being spent on pig-rearing. May I remind him that, because Government recognises the fact that anything to do

Column: 1383

with pork is against the tenets of Islam, a special slaughter house is built for those professing the Muslim faith? Furthermore, although there is a shortage of land, Government does not force cremations.

    Another colleague sought to confuse hon. Members by the introduction of figures to show how many schools he thought it was necessary to build to cope with what he again thought would be the increase in school children. He probably based this on the assumption that the present number of school children would remain school children for the next twenty years. Could not an argument on figures be advanced in favour of crematoriums? Every grave occupies a portion of land. At some time or other, if mathematically calculated, every inch of land would be used by the departed with the increase of the death rate. There is nothing more confusing than to introduce mathematics. The same colleague has on many occasions stressed that the Family Planning Association does not, in fact, advocate birth control but only advises when advice is sought on the spacing out of families. Is he not tying himself up in hopeless contradictions? In one voice he proclaims that birth control is necessary, otherwise a large number of schools will have to be built. He then urges support of the Family Planning Association because this body acts only in an advisory capacity and only when advice is sought.

    Are Members going to be impressed with the fact that the number of persons seeking advice in the spacing out of families has increased from a few hundred to a thousand or even three thousand? What does it matter whether 5,000 people visit the Family Planning Association? What we who are asked to give money are concerned is how that money is being used. We should have a breakdown of these figures. How many of the 3,000 are from the better placed financially; how many are from the literate class and, most important, how

Column: 1384

many are from the illiterate and impoverished classes? Does the Hon. the Financial Secretary, whose obsession and pet baby is the Family Planning Association, give a breakdown of these figures when gladly doling out $100,000 of public money? He is so eaten up and enchanted with the idea of family planning that he does not even seek to satisfy the House on this point.

    On other matters, as hon. Members know full well, such as the building of another hospital, outdoor clinics, increase of medical staff, the expansion of medical and social services, he is most meticulous and every cent that he spends he justifies - and ruthlessly axes every possible project or increase of staff - but now he so generously offers $100,000 without factual statements.

    Many of the hon. Members are naturally impressed with the words "family planning" and therefore quite rightly in their minds agree to help the cause with the firm belief that this will help to prevent an increase of the Singapore population. But do let us be practical and realistic. Have we any genuine evidence, by even a breakdown of figures showing who are benefiting by our money, to satisfy us that our money is being spent in the right direction and the right class of people are being reached? Remember that in the U.K. and the U.S.A. and in fact many countries, the F.P.A. is a voluntary organisation.

    And again, if I may be forgiven for repeating what I said before, Sir, when this point was brought up by the World Health Organisation in the House of Commons, the Minister of Health, on behalf of Her Majesty's Government, replied:

    "The British Government has no intention of imposing birth control on any native territory under its jurisdiction."

And the Parliamentary Secretary to the Ministry of Health went on to say:

    "We have also great responsibilities of our own towards native populations under our jurisdiction. Her Majesty's Government have set themselves against imposing anything of this nature on any territory under our control."

    The Chairman: Will the hon. Member identify the document?

    Mr Braga: I am reading, Sir, from Hansard, Vol. 1, column 1134.

    In Japan where there is only one set of people to deal with, experiments have been carried out in villages where contraceptives are given to married couples and a certain amount of pressure is brought to bear for the use of these. And even abortion is legalised. Although these experiments have shown a reduction of the birth rate in the villages experimented on, there has been no effect whatsoever on the overall birth rate in Japan.

    Here in Singapore, no such compulsion could ever be exercised and a drop in the mighty ocean hardly justifies the expenditure of $100,000, particularly at this time when there is a crying need for other projects which have been curtailed.

    I refuse to be an ostrich, and I plead for a little sane thinking. I ask Members not to be led away by emotion or enthralled by the nomenclature "family planning" without more sound and convincing proof. That is the reason, Sir, why Government has always allowed a free vote and we on this side are allowed amicably to criticise one another.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Mr Speaker, Sir, I have no intention of prolonging this debate. We have had a rather lighthearted debate at times on this subject, but some of the remarks made by my colleague call for clarification because they add more confusion to the whole issue. Sir, let me make my stand clear, first of all.

    On principle, I am against any forced family planning. However, this is not forced family planning. On principle, Sir, I would say that each man has a right to live his own life, to have a family of a size that he feels he should have. Therefore, I will be the first person to oppose anywhere any talk of any forced family planning. It does not mean that even on this particular issue, I support this grant. As I have expressed myself clearly, I have no views either side.

    On the remarks which I made in my speech yesterday about the susceptibilities of Muslims and so on, my hon.

Column: 1386

colleague says that special slaughterhouses are provided for pigs and that Government does not force the use of crematoriums on those who do not wish their dead to be cremated. That is exactly the point, Sir - that there should be no force in matters in which there are religious susceptibilities, and in this particular case, there is no force. This is purely voluntary work carried out by an Association and I said yesterday that I do not know whether they do their work well or not, and nobody is forced to go to this Association and get advice if he does not want it.

    That brings me to the other point and that is - I said it very clearly and I think that I should put it clearer still - I am against family planning in principle; but what I said was that it is not bad as a temporary expedient in our present difficult economic circumstances. I also made it clear that if certain areas of the world, which are underpopulated, were to be opened up so that the surplus population of other areas could be settled there, then family planning would not be necessary at all.

10.30 a.m.

    That brings me, Sir, to another point raised by the hon. Member for Telok Ayer who said that if family planning were carried out by Government, no one would raise any objection to it. Sir, that is difficult to reconcile with his objections to family planning as such. Family planning, if carried out by a Government department, would cost more money; and those who object to it on their own grounds or on religious grounds would have stronger objections because, instead of $100,000 which the Government gives as a grant to the F.P.A., probably a million dollars would be spent on it if the work was carried out by a Government department.

    The second point, Sir, is that once a Government department does this work and allocation has been made in the Budget for it to spend that vote, it becomes the duty of every Government Back-bencher to pass it through this House and, therefore, there can be no free vote; in which case those

Column: 1387

on the Government side who are against family planning cannot oppose and those on the Opposition cannot lobby the Government Back-benchers to support them and there can be no free expression of opinion. Sir, free expression of opinion in this House will be curtailed once family planning comes under a Government department. It will be under the Whip then, which means that there will be no hope of a chance for those who oppose family planning to have the decision reversed, because the Government always have a majority in the House and they will have to carry it through under their Whip. As it now is, Sir, this is a grant to a voluntary organization, and it is a free vote, so those who oppose family planning have ample opportunity to try and get sufficient Members on both sides of the House to say "No" to this grant, in which case the grant will not be given. Therefore, Sir, this gives those who are against it a better opportunity to oppose it than it would if it were under a Government Department, and under the Government Whip in that case.

    The Minister for Education (Mr Chew Swee Kee): Mr Chairman, Sir, my eloquent colleague, the Minister for Health, made it out that I invented mathematics and invented figures. Sir, the figures I quoted were not mine. They are in the 1957 Census Report and I read it properly and carefully. He further said that I assumed that many children would stay in school for 20 years. Now, I said that the statistics prove that in about 10 years' time there will be about one million children under the age of 14. I did not for a moment mean to say that the present children will remain in school for another ten years. What I meant to say was that in another 10 years, one million children will need education.

    He also accused me of contradicting myself by saying that family planning is merely an institution giving advice when sought, and in another breath saying that I advocate birth control. If I have a say in this policy, Sir, I would advocate birth control to stop the perpetuation of human miseries.

Column: 1388



    The Assistant Minister to the Chief Secretary (Mr M. P. D. Nair): Sir, I did not want to speak on this subject, but was prompted to do so because, of all the debates we have ever heard on family planning, this appears to be the most interesting.

    Sir, I have said in this House before that the question of a grant to the Family Planning Association should not be connected with religion, because it would be wrong to argue on religious grounds. I also said, three years ago, that tax-paying Hindus would surely object to the construction of abattoirs where cattle are butchered; likewise the people who believe in various religions are prone to raising objections to all kinds of public expenses.

    Sir, I only want to touch on one or two points which were expressed yesterday by Members opposing this grant to the Family Planning Association. The hon. Member for Changi mentioned that this money should not be handed to a private organization. Sir, I am sure the hon. Member is aware that the Association is a registered voluntary organization, having good objects and aims. All its accounts are produced every year to the Financial Secretary when it applies for a fresh grant. I do not think, Sir, that it is right to argue that this money should be handed to an organization like this.

    The hon. Member also suggested: why cannot the office-bearers of this Association subsidise it with their own money? He implied that they are rich people and that the rings they wear are valued at about $1,000 each. Sir, I think it is quite wrong to ask the officers of a voluntary organization to pay their own money for a public purpose. This organization exists for the welfare of the people, and it is wrong to say that its officers should spend their own money for the public welfare. Sir, the Family Planning Association has always helped and is still helping people in the lower income group. I am indeed surprised that the champions of the poor in this House are opposing it because, by doing so, they are denying to the poor the privilege which is offered by the Association. Sir, I think it is a

Column: 1389

very deserving organization and it needs the fervent support of all Members of the Assembly and of all the people of Singapore in general.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, I cannot see why we should be flogging a dead horse year in and year out. This issue appears to me now to be more or less of a routine nature, and every year, when this question of family planning comes up, there must be someone to introduce a debate on the subject. I am very happy that this is the last Budget on which we are debating, because this is the last term of the present Government. Only those who are re-elected to this Assembly under the new Constitution will have an opportunity to introduce this subject, while those who are very much against family planning would be sore that they are not re-elected and will not be able to bring this subject up again.

    Last year, I expected this subject to come up again for debate this year, and my expectations have come true. But another surprise to me is why hon. Members cannot accept defeat. Every year that it comes up - this is the third time, I presume - it is defeated, and if we are considered honourable enough to he able to introduce legislation in this country, let us be honourable and sporting enough to accept defeat. Let us not try and flog a dead horse year in and year out.

    The second point why I am very glad, Sir, is because the Government have made some changes to the vote to the Association. Last year we were asked to vote for $120,000. This year it has come down to $100,000, a figure which was approved the year before last. This is what I said last year - it appears in the Hansard Vol. 2, No. 44, dated 18th December, 1957 col. 3162:

    "But what I notice, Sir, is the question of the increase in the grant. I think we should concentrate more on the increase in the grant rather than on the actual grant itself. In the year before last, the Association was granted $80,000. Last year, it came up to $100,000. It is now $120,000. As one Member pointed

Column: 1390

out just now, where is this all going to end? Are we going to increase again the grant next year to $140,000, and so on?"

Sir, I am rather happy that the Government have not increased the grant from $120,000 to $140,000, which was the expectation of Members last year. Contrary to that expectation, the Government have now reduced it to $100,000 which was the figure in the previous year's Budget. This was my suggestion and I am very glad that it has been accepted by the Government. Every year I have abstained from voting on this item. This year I am going to vote for it, not because of family planning itself but because Government have accepted my suggestion and stuck to that figure.

    Let us not reduce or increase that sum, because this subject has become so controversial that it has been debated every year. Sir, I am voting for it solely because of the figure of $100,000 and not because of the merits of family planning itself, and also not because I have come over to the Government benches and therefore I should vote for the Government.

    Mr R. C. H. Lim (Nominated): Mr Chairman, Sir, I hope, after me, only the Chief Minister will speak, because we have gone far too long on this very stale subject. However, I cannot let this debate end without expressing my opinion on family planning.

    I believe there are three types of men who find themselves unable to support family planning. The first type is the man - especially if he is a Chinaman - who, having married for the purpose of having a son and heir, finds himself unable to have a son and heir, for every time a child is born to him, it is a girl. Such a man has no use for family planning, because he must try again and again to get a son and heir.

    The second type of man, Sir, is a man who has no child at all. I understand one of the objects of family planning is not to help to procreate, but to help not to procreate. The third type of man, Sir, is rather a regrettable type - an old

Column: 1391

man having reached the age where he finds himself no longer interested in procreation at all.

    There is, however, a different type of man - a man like myself - who has suffered great hardships, because at one time, Sir, I had to support four children who, at the same time, were studying abroad. Sir, if family planning had existed thirty or forty years ago, I am quite sure I would have made use of it, especially in view of the experience which I have had. Sir, may I advise the younger generation that they should go to the Family Planning Association and make use of the services offered, so that in the years to come they may not suffer what I have suffered?

10.45 a.m.

    The Chief Minister (Tun Lim Yew Hock): Mr Speaker, Sir, I had not intended taking part in this debate. I thought yesterday that the best thing for anyone to do was to refer to the Hansards for the past three years and take them as read and then vote as usual! Sir, I have said every year that as this is a matter of conscience, the Government allows a free vote. Every year we have the spectacle of Ministers, who work together under collective responsibility, taking this one opportunity to let their hair down and go at each other's throats!

    Sir, I am indeed surprised that every speaker on this motion has not stood up and said, "I have consulted my wife, and this is what we feel!"

    Mr Lim Cher Kheng: I have!

    The Chief Minister: Sir, my friend there has consulted his wife and he has persuaded her that, according to his calculation, it is cheaper by the dozen! And he admitted that it was cheaper by the dozen.

    Some of us here, Sir, talk of morals. I would ask hon. Members to search their own conscience - as this is a matter of conscience - and think of their own morals. Someone has just talked of sexual lust.

Column: 1392



    When we first started this in 1955, the gallery was packed with women, and the debate which took place then went to the extent of nearly describing the sexual act! Sexual lust! I think it is because women have to satisfy men's sexual lust that they have to be protected! And what is this? Just to protect women? "Mary, thou shalt not have thy sexual lust." But go ahead and have yours! Sir, we want to protect the health of our wives. Have we ever thought of the pains, the fears and worries in the minds of women when they give birth? Have we ever thought of that? We have not. All we think is, "Wonderful, the factory is in full production!" And when the factory is unable to produce, "All right, let us have further factories!" That is not the way to carry on. Family planning is not forced on anyone. If you feel that family planning is going to help you, go ahead and get the benefit. If you feel that it is not going to help you, or if you have any religious opposition to it, do not go to it. Every religion teaches us to be tolerant.
